Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
Good morning on this luminous Monday.
With the cheerful 50-degree weather over the weekend, and more of it expected today, it might feel like springtime.
But don’t expect a burst of blooming flowers here anytime soon.
Even the flower district isn’t heating up yet.
Sure, the shops, which line West 28th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, f
But the flower sellers have it rough “between Christmas bonanza and spring landscaping,” said Monique Blanco, who works at Foliage Garden.
It’s a hard time, she said, because demand is down and the retailers “are all close
to each other, competing for the same clientele.”
The shops sell freshly cut blooms, potted plants and arrangements of artificial flowers to
designers, hotels and restaurants, or to people buying hydrangeas for loved ones.
Between the poinsettias sold around Christmas and the Easter lilies kicking sales back into high
gear at the end of March, Valentine’s Day usually offers a brief respite from a major lull.
But this year saw below-freezing temperatures around the holiday.
obody came in to buy flowers,” said Sukhdev Masih of Paradise Plant, who pointed to the front w
From the outside, though, you’d never know they were concerned.
The shops open as early as 4 a.m., when decorators and event planners usually get first pick.
And by 7 a.m., six-foot tall plants line the block, transforming the street into a colorful jungle.
Here’s what else is happening:
Today should be dry, with lots of sun and a high near 47.
